ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 6: The optional field trip at the end of the course was extremely valuable, and I hope that there will be more opportunities like this (as well as for having guest speakers) if this course is expanded to run during the entire semester.
7) The field trip was a great learning experience!8) The class was much more technical/practice-based than conceptual.

Question 4& 11 go together for me. The pace was fast because there is so much information to cover in a short period of time. Because of this it was mainly lecture and no discussion. When discussions began the instruction allowed them to continue, which was great! The three-hour lecture length was perfect! The course would feel rushed if it was any shorter or split between two meetings/week. The course could be expanded and slowed down, but would have to span more than 6 weeks. There is much more left to explore both in class and in student projects.Question 10: The instructor was incredibly knowledgeable; he talked about the information naturally and knowledgeably. He was realistic about the positives, negatives, potential for success, and time frame of successQuestion 12: The instructor was encouraging about how we as students/the future leaders have the potential to really get in to this field and make a huge impact for the world!

Professor speaks entirely too much about his personal beliefs and opinions, with little connection to the subject matter at hand, pontificates instead of teaching. Someone higher up in the administration should really sit in his class and watch him teac.
This class was a great introduction to the many aspects of agroforestry. The pace was a bit fast becausethere was so much information to fit into a one-credit class that only lasted half a semester.
An amazing class!!!! Not only was it practical, but it helped me to think about my future research. I would take this again!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Field trip was a definite highlight,but I very much enjoyed the course content and professor's teaching style

The readings were interesting and targeted, and supported the lectures well. I especially enjoyed the freedom in choosing a topic of interest for the final assignment, and the instructor was extremely helpful in providing feedback during the brainstorming process. The field trip at the end of the course was one of the highlights of the course.
The field trip. The instructor's enthusiasm and working knowledge of the field.

The three-hour lecture length was perfect! The course would feel rushed if it was any shorter or split between two meetings/week.The field trip was wonderful and very hands on for something you do not get to experience very regularly.

Field trip was really useful and well organized. Also, the class dealt with interesting concepts with lots of detail oriented explanation. It was easy to follow the class because lots of things were coming from the professor's experience.
Practice relevant

Eric was a fantastic teacher. His knowledge and incredible enthusiasm made the course educational and inspiring. The field trip organized for the end of the class was a great experience. We got to see some of the things we had been talking about in person and learn much more than we ever could from lectures by seeing how it is done in practice. Eric was very receptive to student feedback and always able to answer questions. One of the best aspects of the course was the final paper and presentation. I designed a model agroforestry operation for my family's farm, allowing me to explore a topic I was personally very interested in with Eric's feedback and advice. Although the class was a bit lengthy at three hours, it always felt fast-paced and Eric kept it interesting. He is a great lecturer with a passion that is catching. This course would be great expanded into a semester-long class with time to develop a more detailed final project.
The instructor's enthusiasm for the subject and first-hand experience. The field trips, which included hands-on interaction (and tasting) with an edible garden, were worth signing up for alone.
Subject matter

This course was so amazing! Such a great addition to FES, and loved the broad range of agroforestry concepts covered, from tropical to temperate. Great survey course. Hope it will be extended next year.Classmates and their final presentations were fascinating.
The teacher is obviously an expert on this subject. He is an excellent, engaging lecturer. I found his many suggestions as to possible careers/research topics to be inspiring.
The instructor was fantastic. For a 3 hour class, it was extremely engaging. I really enjoyed his perspective and it made me think about sustainability in a different way.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More applied information would have been helpful

It was great to have a practitioner and author provide first-hand experience as a lecturer in this course. I think that the lecture sessions could be improved if they were opened up to more discussion and interaction between students when a question was raised by a classmate. The instructor for this course has a lot of experience leading workshops where he is expected to provide an answer to all of the questions, but I felt that the discussion in class could have been stronger if he had opened up the conversation to more student perspectives.
A 3-hour evening time slot is not ideal, though I understand it also depends on instructor availability.

The student presentations were an excellent way to get us exploring, but it made for a very long class to hear from everyone in one sitting.I wished there had more discussion about the readings, but the short 6-week length of the class put the focus on lecture material over deeper exploration.

It might be better to be offered in a longer period time for 3 credits since there are lots of things that the class can deal with. Also, the class time was not best. Concentrating on class materials at 6PM in the afternoon was not easy.
The professor needs to tie his theories with practical applications. Very pie in the sky, the readings had little connection to the lectures and were not discussed in the least
The only comment on this is the short length of the course - Eric had so much information and we could have learned a lot more if we had an entire semester.

The instructor included some of the environmental benefits (particularly carbon sequestration) of the agroforestry practices surveyed. Given the audience (which includes many students active in carbon science and addressing the challenge of greenhouse gases), the discussion on the impacts of higher greenhouse gases could have been reduced to a slide or two, with remaining time used for more exploration of specific agroforestry concepts.
As a single-credit course, there wasn't ample opportunity to explore material in depth.

Would love to have more field trips and a more practical side. Eric mentioned that he teaches a practical course that is full time for about a week or 9 hours, and I would love for that material to be combined into a full semester course along with the previous material. Just because we are in an academic setting doesn't mean we are not willing to get our hands dirty!

The surveys of useful plants were exhaustive in relation to the conceptual content covered. While interesting, I'm not sure if many people got a whole lot from them, other than the idea that there are many useful plants out there. With such limited time as a 1 credit course has, maybe less time going over lists of plants is better.The part of this course that needs most improvement is teacher feedback. I submitted a final project and, as of yet, have received no feedback on it. If we don't receive feedback from work we do in school a large part of our learning potential is wasted.
Make the course a semester long instead of 6 weeks

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No discussion section
A little more interaction/ engagement of the students could be good.
N/A
The field trip was a perfect capstone to the course.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am studying working lands management and agriculture.
I think it is really important to learn about Agroforestry at our school. Learning a broader concept of agroforestry that includes climate change mitigation was really interesting and helpful.

I am studying environmental management with a focus on land use and agriculture so this course was an excellent addition to my program of study. It expanded my knowledge on an emerging, and important, field. As Eric pointed out to us, agroforestry is not just a topic related to agriculture - it combines aspects of business, engineering, energy use, climate change, and forestry together. I believe this would be a great course for anyone who wants to think about where and how we will use land to get our resources in the future.

It is a perfect supplement to traditional forestry courses. Agroforestry is sorely needed in the school curriculum as it is a necessary tool to improve land use and make it more intelligent than just forestry or agriculture alone.
Came back to this masters program very interested in tropical agroforestry. Hope FES will bring in more courses like this in the future.

As someone who has done some agroforestry work before this course is a great, more formal introduction to the field. It serves well as a brief introduction; I would love for it to be followed by many more courses of greater depth on this topic.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am very interested in Agroforestry (Master of forestry student), and was drawn to any course in the topic area
I thought it would be a really cool topic to learn about from an actual practitioner.

I took this course to explore a field that is rapidly developing in America for various reasons. People are concerned about food sovereignty and safety all over the world, so having some concept of how this could be achieved seems essential!

Two main reasons: the first is that I am personally interested because my family owns a 200-acre farm. The second is that I have heard about it more and more but knew little about how agroforestry actually worked and what the applications were.
Professional interests, for use later in life as an implementer of such systems.
To learn formally about a broad range of agroforestry techniques.
Because of my interest in this field. Also, the reputation of the teacher as a great lecturer and writer in the field.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes. I did not have specific expectations, but this course served to expand my awareness and knowledge of agroforestry topics beyond the background I already had
Yes.

The class was really practical. The most helpful thing for me was designing agroforestry systems by using the criteria that we learned in the class. Also, I could get constructive comments on my paper after presentation from classmates and the professor.
Yes! Great overview of under-valued topics in land use!
No.
Yes, and then some!

The course was very good at describing basic concepts and introducing us to the potential of many plants around the world. What I felt was lacking and could be included in a full-semester course, potentially co-taught, was discussion ofresearch in the field and practical, commercial application of agroforestry concepts. This could include work as is published by members of the Association for Temperate Agroforestry or the University of Missouri Agroforestry center.
Absolutely, and much more.
Yes, for a 1-credit introductory course it met my expectations.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I would suggest that students ask for a full semester version of this course, and take advantage of the lecturerâs expertise by asking questions outside of class about any related topics of interest.
It's fun and will give you a lot of practical information, but don't expect much in the way of broader analysis or conceptual context.
Trying to find a real project for the class presentation. It will be a great opportunity to others' feedback on the topic.
Take it!
Do not take it, the professor comes across as inexperienced and does not provide any value added to the lecture and reading materials. Read a book instead.
Definitely take it! Think early about the topic you might want to pursue for a final paper and presentation because Eric is a great resource if you start talking to him early.

This is a fantastic introduction to agroforestry taught by a very passionate practitioner, capped off with an awesome field trip. It could be improved with more commercial examples and a review of academic literature to complement the instructor's own experience.
Take it - it is absolutely great. Whether you are in the tropics or temperate zone, it has a lot to offer.
Do the readings.
